description:
This refactors Grid IO so that instead of including lots of logic about fluid selection in each `BaseIOHandler` subclass, we do it in the base class (like we do for particles).  It also implements a very simple LRU caching scheme, currently disabled, for IO caching.

Because of how this defines `read_fluid_selection`, it's a non-invasive change, and instead can be spread throughout the code gradually.

I'm still thinking through the API; if you look at the commits, you can see I experimented with different ways of setting up the reading of objects.

The ultimate goal here is twofold:

 * Short-term, get this in, make the grid visitors PR use it so that it can be independent of the IO ordering.  This should allow us to get rid of the slowest parts of the indexing and instead use the visitors.
 * Long-term, use this as a mechanism to allow for numeric slicing of data objects, thus exposing them to things like dask.

Right now, performance isn't *that* much better with this, or with caching, for most things.  Selection is still the slow part.

I've tagged some reviewers that do grid frontends and the like.
title: Refactor Grid IO

content.raw:
Perhaps I am missing something. Should it be possible to implement preload using the new API as well?

(Actually I'm sure I'm missing something, because I don't 100% understand how preload hooks into the rest of the IO machinery.)

content.raw:
Some brief comments/questions. I apologize if they are naive.

1. I really like the `io_iter` machinery. This feels like a very clean API which makes things a lot easier to handle.
2. I am confused about what pieces of the old machinery are required and what pieces are no longer required. Does `_read_chunk_data` still need to exist? And if so, can it too be implemented via io_iter? It would be very nice to merge these two bits of code, since (at least in my frontend) `_read_fluid_selections` calls `_read_chunk_data`. Requiring both `_read_chunk_data` and `io_iter` would result in a lot of duplicated code.
3. Shouldn't the name be `_io_iter` for consistency?
content.html:
Some brief comments/questions. I apologize if they are naive.

  1. I really like the io_iter machinery. This feels like a very clean API which makes things a lot easier to handle.
  2. I am confused about what pieces of the old machinery are required and what pieces are no longer required. Does _read_chunk_data still need to exist? And if so, can it too be implemented via io_iter? It would be very nice to merge these two bits of code, since (at least in my frontend) _read_fluid_selections calls _read_chunk_data. Requiring both _read_chunk_data and io_iter would result in a lot of duplicated code.
  3. Shouldn't the name be _io_iter for consistency?

content.raw:
As a note, I have dug into some of the answer test failures.  Some have been fixed, in a commit that fixed some iteration loops.

The Enzo grid values are currently changing because they are being cast to `f8` before getting the hashlib sum.  I was able to verify that casting to `>f4` before taking the hash results in answer tests for GridValues passing where they didn't before.  I'm going to continue to see if I can get the results to be identical, as I think that is a more stable solution in the long term.
content.html:
As a note, I have dug into some of the answer test failures. Some have been fixed, in a commit that fixed some iteration loops.

The Enzo grid values are currently changing because they are being cast to f8 before getting the hashlib sum. I was able to verify that casting to >f4 before taking the hash results in answer tests for GridValues passing where they didn't before. I'm going to continue to see if I can get the results to be identical, as I think that is a more stable solution in the long term.

content.html: Whoops! No, it doesn't. (fid, data) = (None, None) would work though.

content.raw: Just curious, is there a benefit to creating and passing an empty array over having h5py do everything?
content.html: Just curious, is there a benefit to creating and passing an empty array over having h5py do everything?

content.raw: If the try/except faster than checking if "Dark_Matter_Density" exists in the group?
content.html: If the try/except faster than checking if "Dark_Matter_Density" exists in the group?

content.raw: So, that's a good question.  Yes, kind of.  So in the old method, *definitely*.  Here, *probably*.  We are reusing the array for each field, so we save on allocations, especially because we only ever use this as an input to a selection that copies (at the very least, to fix the F/C ordering.)  If we provide an array that is ordered the same as the on-disk HDF5 array, it will copy it in stride-1 straight from disk to memory.  If we supply C to an F array for instance, it will not do this, and instead do a value-by-value copy.  So I think so, and definitely there was before.
content.html: So, that's a good question. Yes, kind of. So in the old method, definitely. Here, probably. We are reusing the array for each field, so we save on allocations, especially because we only ever use this as an input to a selection that copies (at the very least, to fix the F/C ordering.) If we provide an array that is ordered the same as the on-disk HDF5 array, it will copy it in stride-1 straight from disk to memory. If we supply C to an F array for instance, it will not do this, and instead do a value-by-value copy. So I think so, and definitely there was before.

content.raw: Yes, disappointingly, it is.  I don't remember how big the difference is, but I think it can be really substantial if you're dealing with a lot of leaf nodes and datasets.
content.html: Yes, disappointingly, it is. I don't remember how big the difference is, but I think it can be really substantial if you're dealing with a lot of leaf nodes and datasets.

content.raw: Interesting, ok.
content.html: Interesting, ok.

content.raw: OK, fair enough.
content.html: OK, fair enough.

content.raw: This definitely cuts down on the duplicate code.  I'm in favor of this for that alone.  The rest looks correct to me.  What is the plan for enabling the lru caching?  Does it need to be tested against having it off, either for speed or accuracy?
content.html: This definitely cuts down on the duplicate code. I'm in favor of this for that alone. The rest looks correct to me. What is the plan for enabling the lru caching? Does it need to be tested against having it off, either for speed or accuracy?

content.raw:
Thanks!

For the LRU, I actually want to do some testing for speed before enabling it, but we also need to figure out how to make it globally tunable.  For instance, if we were to do a time series iteration and we had dataset-level caching enabled, we might end up in a case where we cache *all* of the grids for all the datasets, and then wouldn't be able to clear it.
content.html:
Thanks!

For the LRU, I actually want to do some testing for speed before enabling it, but we also need to figure out how to make it globally tunable. For instance, if we were to do a time series iteration and we had dataset-level caching enabled, we might end up in a case where we cache all of the grids for all the datasets, and then wouldn't be able to clear it.

content.raw: Just a heads up that this will be substantially slower than the C LRU Cache implementation in `fastcache`. Maybe it's possible to monkeypatch that so you can use a different implementation for `make_key`, avoiding defining `local_lru_cache`.

content.raw:
I spent time looking at the current failures.  There is an asymmetry in how we do copying of field values in FLASH and Enzo.  When I fix this in favor of how Enzo did it (i.e., use an early exit with a check on the `GridSelector` object) it works for the enzo tests, but breaks FLASH.  Reverse is also true.

The reason this happens is that right now, if you ask a 32-bit FLASH file for a value from a grid directly, it gives you a 64-bit value.  Enzo returns 32-bit for 32-bit on a grid-by-grid basis.

I'm inclined to leave the change as it is right now in this PR, and regenerate new answer results for FLASH.  What this would do is make it so that if you ask a 32-bit FLASH file for a set of grid values, they come back as 32-bit.  Same for Enzo.

With that being said, I think this is ready for review; I got some feedback already and I will try to incorporate that in the next day or so.
content.html:
I spent time looking at the current failures. There is an asymmetry in how we do copying of field values in FLASH and Enzo. When I fix this in favor of how Enzo did it (i.e., use an early exit with a check on the GridSelector object) it works for the enzo tests, but breaks FLASH. Reverse is also true.

The reason this happens is that right now, if you ask a 32-bit FLASH file for a value from a grid directly, it gives you a 64-bit value. Enzo returns 32-bit for 32-bit on a grid-by-grid basis.

I'm inclined to leave the change as it is right now in this PR, and regenerate new answer results for FLASH. What this would do is make it so that if you ask a 32-bit FLASH file for a set of grid values, they come back as 32-bit. Same for Enzo.

With that being said, I think this is ready for review; I got some feedback already and I will try to incorporate that in the next day or so.
